name: Alex Chen
interview_summary: My bookshelf is entirely filled with biographies of disruptors like Elon Musk and copies of 'Zero to One' by Peter Thiel. I deeply respect those who rewrite the rules of the game. Nothing irritates me more than seeing inefficient systems or ugly, non-functional designs—I feel a physical need to fix them. People often say I could talk my way out of anything, but I prefer using that skill to pitch ideas. I harbor a deep anger towards how resources are hoarded and wasted while the world burns; I want to build ventures that scale solutions to these massive inequality problems.

name: Sarah Jenkins
interview_summary: I don't really care about fame; I respect Linus Torvalds for building the infrastructure of the modern world from a basement. I recently snapped at a teammate who kept using buzzwords without understanding the underlying code—I can't stand superficiality. My happiest moments are at 3 AM, completely zoned in, debugging a complex kernel issue. My shelf is just O'Reilly technical manuals. It makes me furious to see technology becoming a tool for surveillance and control rather than liberation. I want to build systems that protect privacy and truth.

name: Elena Rodriguez
interview_summary: I have endless admiration for Jane Addams and her grassroots community work. My room is piling up with ethnographies and books on restorative justice. I get incredibly impatient when people dismiss others' emotions as 'irrational' or 'unproductive'—empathy is a valid form of intelligence! I feel most alive when I'm facilitating a difficult dialogue between opposing groups and finding common ground. I am angry that our society prioritizes GDP over human well-being. I want to redesign community structures to ensure no one is left isolated.

name: Hiroshi Tanaka
interview_summary: I look up to Warren Buffett, not just for the money, but for his incredible patience and discipline. I recently got annoyed when our project lead kept changing the timeline last minute—unpredictability stresses me out. I feel most capable when I'm organizing complex datasets into a perfectly balanced spreadsheet; there's a peace in order. I buy books on economic history and investment strategies. It frustrates me to see people fall into debt due to a lack of financial literacy. I want to create stable, long-term wealth management systems for families.

name: Jordan Lee
interview_summary: I worship Hayao Miyazaki for his ability to craft entire worlds that feel more real than reality. I spend all my money on expensive art books and graphic novels. I have zero patience for bureaucracy or people who say 'we've always done it this way'—it kills the soul. My peak moments are when I'm sketching and realize I haven't eaten in six hours. I'm angry that the world forces adults to kill their inner child to survive. I want to create animation that allows people to escape and rediscover their imagination.

name: Priya Patel
interview_summary: I deeply respect Brené Brown for teaching the world that vulnerability is strength. My bookshelf is a mix of trauma research and mindfulness guides. I get frustrated with 'hustle culture' that treats rest as a weakness. I feel most fulfilled when a friend tells me, 'I've never told anyone this before'—being a safe harbor is my natural state. It angers me that mental health care is a luxury privilege rather than a basic right. I want to build accessible healing spaces where people aren't judged for their pain.

name: André Chiang
interview_summary: I don't cook to feed people; I cook to evoke memories. I admire Jiro Ono for his relentless pursuit of perfection in a single domain. I have no tolerance for 'good enough' or sloppy plating—every detail must be intentional. My flow state happens in the heat of the kitchen, orchestrating the pass like a conductor. I read books on fermentation chemistry and agricultural history. It breaks my heart to see fast food destroying our connection to the land and our palate. I want to create sustainable dining experiences that honor the ingredients.
